Let $r\geq 4$. If $G$ is a graph on $n$ vertices with at least $\mathrm{ex}(n;K_r)$ edges then must $G$ contain a vertex with degree $d\gg_r n$ whose neighbourhood contains at least $\mathrm{ex}(d;K_{r-1})$ edges?



As Erd\H{o}s \cite{Er75} says 'if true this would be a nice generalisation of Tur\'{a}n's theorem'.

This is true (unless $G$ it itself the Tur\'{a}n graph), and was proved by Bollob\'{a}s and Thomason \cite{BoTh81}. Bondy \cite{Bo83b} showed that if $G$ has $>\mathrm{ex}(n;K_r)$ edges then the corresponding vertex can be chosen to be of maximum degree in $G$.




References


[Bo83b] Bondy, J. A., Large dense neighbourhoods and {T}ur\'an's theorem. J. Combin. Theory Ser. B (1983), 109--111.

[BoTh81] Bollob\'as, B\'{e}la and Thomason, Andrew, Dense neighbourhoods and {T}ur\'an's theorem. J. Combin. Theory Ser. B (1981), 111--114.

[Er75] Erd\H{o}s, P., Some recent progress on extremal problems in graph theory. Congr. Numer. (1975), 3-14.
